document: 2026 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke

recommendation_trial_maps.summary: Hospitals treating patients with acute stroke should engage in a multicomponent QI process that involves the continuous monitoring, review, and feedback of stroke quality indicators, benchmarks, and evidence-based practices, in order to increase quality of care, improve patient outcomes, and reduce health care disparities.
Hospitals treating patients with acute stroke should participate in stroke data registries to increase the adherence to quality indicators and guideline recommendations and improve patient outcomes.

Hospitals treating patients with acute stroke should measure and document baseline stroke severity (eg, NIHSS score) in all acute stroke patients so that risk adjustment models used to compare hospital performance can be sufficiently accurate and reliable.
Educational programs on stroke recognition for all ages to improve stroke preparedness
Educational programs should reach diverse communities to reduce knowledge gaps
Educational programs should be sustained over time to improve long-term knowledge
Targeted stroke education for EMS, physicians, and health care personnel to reduce prehospital delays
Establish regional systems of stroke care for access to time-sensitive therapies and rapid transport to EVT centers
Develop prehospital triage protocols for rapid stroke identification and transport to appropriate centers
Monitoring and feedback on prehospital care quality metrics can reduce delays and increase discharge to home
EMS dispatch use of a telephone stroke assessment tool is reasonable for early identification of stroke.
Use of a brief stroke assessment tool by prehospital personnel is recommended to improve early stroke identification.
Prehospital personnel should provide advance notification to the receiving hospital of an inbound suspected stroke.
Ambulance-initiated remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) with arm BP cuff inflation is not recommended.
Prehospital initiation of stroke treatment with transdermal glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) is potentially harmful.
Intensive BP control in the field to a target of 130 to 140 mm Hg systolic does not improve functional outcome.
Usefulness of common adult stroke screening tools in pediatric patients is uncertain; newer pediatric tools' value remains to be determined.
EMS should prioritize transport to the closest appropriate facility to reduce time to treatment.
Direct transport to a TSC can be beneficial for suspected LVO stroke to increase EVT rates and reduce time to treatment.

In areas without well-coordinated SSOC and local hospital(s) proficient in thrombolysis delivery and transfer, direct transport of suspected LVO patients to the closest appropriate TSC may be reasonable.

In areas with well-coordinated SSOC and local hospital(s) proficient in thrombolysis delivery and transfer, direct transport to a distant TSC (eg, 45–60 min) does not improve 3-month clinical outcomes.
Hospitals and EMS should establish agreements and protocols to prioritize interhospital transfer to reduce DIDO times.
MSUs recommended for thrombolytic-eligible patients to ensure fastest onset-to-treatment time and improve outcomes
MSUs must be equipped to diagnose and treat with IVT
MSU care with streamlined protocols and neurological expertise is beneficial for emergent evaluation and treatment
MSUs can be beneficial for triage of thrombectomy-eligible patients to appropriate facility with prehospital notification
Certification as a stroke specialty hospital by an external credentialing agency is recommended
Organized protocol for emergent evaluation of acute neurological deficits in all ages
Suspect acute stroke in pediatric patients with sudden onset and ongoing focal neurological deficits, including first-time seizure
Designation of acute stroke team for suspected stroke patients
Development and education of multidisciplinary stroke teams to increase IVT treatment rates
Stroke teams for thrombolytic-eligible and EVT-eligible patients to ensure fastest onset-to-treatment time
Prehospital telemedicine for suspected stroke in ambulance to complement paramedic assessment for reperfusion candidate identification
Teleradiology for AIS patients in EDs without in-house imaging expertise for timely brain imaging review and IVT decision-making
Telestroke for IVT decision-making and administration in AIS patients in EDs without acute neurological expertise
Telestroke to reduce short-term mortality in AIS patients at hospitals without local stroke expertise
Telephone consultation with stroke specialist for IVT decision-making and EVT eligibility in AIS patients without in-house stroke expertise or telestroke
Support for telemedicine/telestroke resources to ensure 24/7 coverage for AIS patients
Telestroke for triage and interfacility transfer for emergency EVT versus local care in AIS patients at hospitals with telestroke capability
Hospitals should participate in an accountable SSOC that consists of an integrated network of certified hospitals and prehospital EMS systems for optimal acute stroke care.
Hospitals without 24/7 thrombectomy should develop interhospital transfer protocols for EVT-eligible patients.
PSC hospitals without 24/7 thrombectomy should rapidly perform and interpret vascular imaging to identify LVO eligible for EVT.
Hospitals should adopt care protocols reflecting current clinical guidelines from professional organizations or agencies.
Hospitals providing EVT should track key time metrics, care processes, and long-term outcomes.
Hospitals providing EVT should credential neurointerventionalists using established standards.
ASRH relying on transfers can consider rapid vascular imaging to identify LVO eligible for EVT.
SSOC may consider developing mobile intervention teams for timely EVT delivery.
Use of a stroke severity rating scale, preferably NIHSS, is recommended for measuring clinical deficits at baseline and after reperfusion therapies.
Protocols for emergent brain imaging within 25 minutes to facilitate reperfusion interventions
Emergent vascular imaging with CTA/CTP should not be delayed for serum creatinine in LVO
MRI/MRA for pediatric AIS to identify LVO and differentiate stroke types
CT/CTA for pediatric AIS if MRI/MRA not available within 25 minutes
MRI DWI-FLAIR mismatch for IVT eligibility in wake-up/unknown onset >4.5h
CTP or MR DWI-PWI with automated analysis for IVT eligibility in 4.5-24h window
Adjunctive CTP, MRI (DWI-FLAIR mismatch), or MR DWI-PWI for EVT evaluation in 6-24h window
DTAS for flat-panel head CT vs conventional imaging in LVO with RACE >4 and EVT eligibility
DTAS without repeat imaging for emergently transferred LVO patients eligible for EVT
Baseline ECG in suspected acute stroke
Baseline troponin in suspected acute stroke
Hemodynamic augmentation using hemodilution, high-dose albumin, or chemical vasodilators is not recommended
Mechanical hemodynamic augmentation with counterpulsation devices or sphenopalatine ganglion stimulation is not recommended
Neuroprotective agents are not recommended in AIS
Emergent carotid endarterectomy (within 48 hours) for high-grade carotid stenosis or occlusion without intracranial occlusion is not beneficial
Airway support and ventilatory assistance for acute stroke with decreased consciousness or bulbar dysfunction
Supplemental oxygen for AIS with hypoxia to maintain SpO2 >94%
NBO before EVT for AIS within 6h, NIHSS 10-20, ASPECTS ≥6, anterior circulation LVO
HBO for AIS due to arterial air embolism
Supplemental oxygen not recommended for AIS without hypoxia, ineligible for EVT
HBO not recommended for AIS not associated with air embolism
No benefit of routine 0-degree head positioning compared with 30 degrees for 24 hours in AIS overall
No benefit of routine Trendelenburg positioning (−20 degrees) compared with 0- to 30-degree head positioning in AIS with probable large artery atherosclerosis and no reperfusion intervention
Correct hypotension and hypovolemia in AIS to maintain systemic perfusion.
Early treatment of hypertension in AIS when required by comorbid conditions.
Benefit of treating BP ≥220/120 mm Hg within 48-72h in AIS without IVT/EVT or urgent comorbidities is uncertain.
Treating BP <220/120 mm Hg within 48-72h in AIS without IVT/EVT or urgent comorbidities is not effective.
Lower SBP to <185 mm Hg and DBP <110 mm Hg before IVT in eligible AIS patients.
Maintain BP ≤185/110 mm Hg before EVT if no IVT.
Maintain BP <180/105 mm Hg for at least 24h after IVT.
Intensive SBP reduction (<140 mm Hg vs <180 mm Hg) after IVT in mild-moderate AIS is not recommended.
Maintain BP ≤180/105 mm Hg during and for 24h after EVT.
Intensive SBP reduction target of <140 mm Hg for 72h after successful EVT for anterior LVO is harmful.
Targeting normothermia in AIS patients with hyperthermia is recommended
Identify and treat sources of hyperthermia in AIS patients
Induced hypothermia or prophylactic fever prevention is not recommended in AIS patients with normothermia
Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL) in AIS
Treat persistent hyperglycemia to achieve blood glucose 140-180 mg/dL
IV insulin to achieve blood glucose 80-130 mg/dL not recommended
In adult patients with AIS with disabling deficits, regardless of NIHSS score, and eligible for IVT, faster treatment improves functional outcomes.

In adult patients with AIS who are eligible for IVT within 4.5 hours of symptom onset, treatment should be initiated as quickly as possible, assuring safe administration and avoiding potential delays associated with additional multimodal neuroimaging.
In patients with AIS undergoing IVT, health care professionals should be prepared to treat potential emergent adverse effects, including bleeding complications and angioedema.

In patients with AIS eligible for IVT, health care professionals should discuss its potential risks and benefits with competent patients and/or available patient representatives, when feasible, to ensure shared decision-making.

In patients with suspected ischemic stroke, treating health care professionals should determine blood glucose levels before IVT initiation to assess and urgently treat severe hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.

In patients with suspected ischemic stroke with severe hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia, if symptoms of disabling stroke persist despite correction to normoglycemia, administration of IVT is recommended.

In patients with AIS who are otherwise eligible for IVT with early ischemic change of mild to moderate extent (other than frank hypodensity attributable to the clinical presentation) on initial brain imaging, IVT is recommended.
In eligible adult patients with AIS presenting with mild non-disabling stroke deficits within 4.5 hours of symptom onset or last known well, IVT is not recommended.
In suspected patients with AIS who are taking single or DAPT and are otherwise eligible for IVT, IVT is recommended to improve functional outcomes despite an increase in risk of sICH.

In patients with AIS within 4.5 hours of last known well and eligible for IVT, it is reasonable that IVT not be delayed while waiting for hematologic or coagulation testing if there is no reason to suspect an abnormal result.

In patients with AIS who are eligible for IVT within 4.5 hours of symptom onset with unknown burden of cerebral microbleeds (CMB), it is recommended that IVT be administered without first obtaining MRI to exclude CMBs.

In patients with AIS within 4.5 hours of last known well and who are eligible for IVT, administration of IVT is reasonable to achieve better functional outcomes if a small number (eg, 1–10) of CMBs was demonstrated on MRI.

In patients with AIS within 4.5 hours of last known well and who are eligible for IVT, if they previously had a high burden (eg, >10) of CMBs demonstrated on MRI, usefulness of IVT is uncertain as it may be associated with an increased risk of sICH.

In pediatric patients aged 28 days to 18 years with confirmed AIS presenting within 4.5 hours of symptom onset and disabling deficits, IVT with alteplase may be considered as it is safe, but efficacy is uncertain.
Tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg (max 25 mg) or alteplase 0.9 mg/kg within 4.5h for adult AIS eligible for IVT
Tenecteplase 0.4 mg/kg within 4.5h for adult AIS eligible for IVT is not recommended
IVT within 4.5 hours from symptom recognition for unknown onset, MRI-DWI lesion < one-third MCA, no marked FLAIR change
IVT 4.5–9 hours from last known well OR within 9 hours from midpoint of sleep (wake-up stroke), salvageable penumbra on perfusion imaging
IVT 4.5 to 24 hours from symptom onset or last known well, LVO, salvageable penumbra, cannot receive EVT
IV reteplase within 4.5h, not undergoing EVT, may be considered
IV mutant prourokinase within 4.5h, not undergoing EVT, may be considered
IV desmoteplase within 3-9h not recommended
IV mutant prourokinase + low-dose alteplase within 4.5h not recommended
IV urokinase within 6h not beneficial
IV streptokinase within 6h should not be administered
Sonothrombolysis adjunct to IVT not recommended
IVT for AIS with known sickle cell disease in adults
IVT for acute nonarteritic CRAO with disabling visual loss within 4.5 hours in adults
IVT is safe and recommended in AIS patients eligible for both IVT and EVT
IVT should be administered as rapidly as possible without delay for EVT
EVT for mRS 0-1, ASPECTS 3-10, 0-6h
EVT for mRS 0-1, ASPECTS ≥6, 6-24h
EVT for mRS 0-1, ASPECTS 3-5, age <80, 6-24h, no mass effect
EVT for mRS 0-1, ASPECTS 0-2, age <80, 0-6h, no mass effect
EVT for mRS 2, ASPECTS ≥6, 0-6h
EVT for mRS 3-4, ASPECTS ≥6, 0-6h
EVT for dominant proximal M2, mRS 0-1, ASPECTS ≥6, 0-6h
No EVT for nondominant M2/distal/ACA/PCA, 0-6h
EVT for basilar occlusion, mRS 0-1, NIHSS ≥10, PC-ASPECTS ≥6, within 24h
EVT for basilar occlusion, mRS 0-1, NIHSS 6-9, PC-ASPECTS ≥6, within 24h
EVT with stent retrievers, contact aspiration, or combination techniques is recommended for LVO
Reperfusion to extended TICI grade 2b/2c/3 as early as possible is recommended
General anesthesia or procedural sedation are recommended to facilitate EVT
Use of a proximal balloon to guide catheters remains uncertain
EVT with stent retrievers is of no benefit for medium/distal anterior, middle (nondominant/codominant M2, M3), or posterior cerebral arteries
Acute treatment of both tandem extracranial-intracranial anterior circulation occlusions, including emergent extracranial stenting, may be reasonable
Rescue intracranial balloon angioplasty and/or stenting in failed EVT remains uncertain
Adjunctive intraarterial thrombolytics after EVT may be reasonable
Preoperative tirofiban before EVT is not useful for LVO
EVT for pediatric patients ≥6 years, LVO, within 6 hours from symptom onset
EVT for pediatric patients ≥6 years, LVO, 6 to 24 hours from symptom onset, potentially salvageable brain tissue
EVT for pediatric patients aged 28 days to 6 years, LVO, within 24 hours from symptom onset, potentially salvageable brain tissue
Aspirin recommended within 48 hours after AIS onset
IV tirofiban efficacy not well established in AIS
IV abciximab not recommended in AIS due to bleeding
Antiplatelet preferred over anticoagulation for noncardioembolic AIS/TIA
Antiplatelet or anticoagulant for ≥3 months in AIS with extracranial carotid/vertebral dissection
Effectiveness of changing/increasing aspirin in noncardioembolic stroke/TIA unclear
Ticagrelor not recommended over aspirin for minor noncardioembolic AIS/high-risk TIA
Triple antiplatelet therapy not recommended for noncardioembolic ischemic stroke
Adding antiplatelet to anticoagulation in ischemic stroke with AF (no CAD/stent) is harmful
DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) for minor AIS/high-risk TIA (NIHSS ≤3, ABCD2 ≥4) within 24h, 21 days, then SAPT
DAPT (ticagrelor + aspirin) for 30 days may be considered for recent (<24h) minor AIS/high-risk TIA (NIHSS ≤5, ABCD2 ≥6, ≥50% stenosis)
DAPT (clopidogrel + aspirin) for 21 days then SAPT for minor AIS/high-risk TIA (NIHSS ≤5 or 4-5 within 24h, ABCD2 ≥4, ≥50% stenosis) within 24-72h or NIHSS 4-5 within 24h
DAPT (ticagrelor + aspirin) for 21 days (then ticagrelor alone) may be reasonable for minor AIS/high-risk TIA (NIHSS ≤3, ABCD2 ≥4, CYP2C19 LOF allele) within 24h
IV eptifibatide not recommended adjunctively with IVT within 3h of AIS onset
Early oral anticoagulation poststroke in selected AIS with AF is reasonable
Urgent anticoagulation in AIS with ipsilateral, high-grade ICA stenosis: benefit not well established
Short-term anticoagulation in AIS with ipsilateral, nonocclusive, extracranial intraluminal thrombus: safety/efficacy not well established
Anticoagulation in AIS with HT may be considered depending on scenario/indication
Argatroban as adjunct to IVT in AIS is not effective for long-term functional outcomes
Early anticoagulation (within 48 hours of stroke onset) in AIS is not recommended
Stroke unit care for AIS, all ages
Bedside swallow screening prior to liquid or food intake is recommended to screen for aspiration risk.
Dysphagia screening by speech pathologists or other trained health care professionals is reasonable.
Endoscopic examination of swallowing function is reasonable for patients unable to participate in bedside screening.
Oral hygiene protocol may be reasonable to reduce pneumonia risk.
Pharyngeal electrical stimulation (PES) can be beneficial to reduce dysphagia severity and aspiration risk.
PES after ventilator weaning can be beneficial for severe stroke patients with dysphagia requiring tracheotomy and mechanical ventilation.
Enteral diet should be started within 7 days of admission after AIS
Nutritional screening is recommended early, preferably within 48 hours of admission, using a validated tool
For AIS with dysphagia, nasogastric tubes are reasonable within first 7 days; percutaneous gastrostomy for >2–3 weeks inability to swallow
IPC in addition to routine care is recommended over routine care alone to reduce the risk of DVT in AIS patients with impaired mobility and no contraindications to IPC.
Prophylactic-dose subcutaneous heparin (UFH or LMWH) is reasonable to reduce the risk of VTE in AIS patients with impaired mobility.
Benefit of prophylactic-dose subcutaneous heparin (UFH or LMWH) over no prophylactic-dose heparin is not well established to increase overall survival in AIS patients with impaired mobility.
Benefit of prophylactic-dose LMWH over prophylactic-dose UFH to prevent DVT is uncertain in AIS patients with impaired mobility selected for prophylactic anticoagulation.
Elastic compression stockings cause harm, including skin breakdown, ulceration, and tissue necrosis, compared with usual care in AIS patients with impaired mobility.
Structured depression inventory screening for poststroke depression in AIS patients
Antidepressants and/or nonpharmacological interventions for patients with PSD
Referral to palliative care resources is reasonable for select patients with AIS and their families.
Routine use of prophylactic antibiotics has not been shown to be beneficial in improving functional outcomes in patients with AIS.
Routine placement of indwelling bladder catheters should not be performed in patients with AIS due to risk of catheter-associated UTIs.
In-hospital, formal, interdisciplinary assessment and provision of rehabilitation is recommended to improve functional recovery.
SSRIs are not effective for improving motor recovery or functional status.
High-dose, very early mobilization within 24 hours of stroke onset is not recommended and may be harmful.
Early discussion of care options and outcomes for large cerebral/cerebellar infarctions at high risk for brain swelling/herniation
Close monitoring for neurological worsening after large cerebral/cerebellar infarctions
Early transfer to institution with neurosurgical/critical care expertise for large cerebral/cerebellar infarctions at increased risk for malignant brain swelling
Osmotic therapy as bridge to surgery for large cerebral/cerebellar infarctions with neurological decline from brain swelling
IV glibenclamide not recommended for large hemispheric infarction age 18-70
Hypothermia, barbiturates, corticosteroids should not be used for brain swelling in large infarctions
Decompressive hemicraniectomy for large territorial cerebral infarctions at high risk for brain swelling and herniation, with decreased level of consciousness
Decompressive craniectomy with dural expansion for unilateral MCA infarctions in patients ≤60 years, within 48 hours from brain swelling, with neurological deterioration despite medical therapy
Decompressive craniectomy with dural expansion for unilateral MCA infarctions in patients >60 years, within 48 hours from brain swelling, with neurological deterioration despite medical therapy
Early decompressive craniectomy within 48 hours for AIS patients who received IV tPA and develop malignant cerebral edema despite medical therapy
Ventriculostomy for cerebellar infarction with obstructive hydrocephalus
Decompressive suboccipital craniectomy with dural expansion for cerebellar infarction with neurological deterioration from brainstem compression or volumes ≥35 mL
Antiseizure medication recommended for unprovoked seizure after AIS in adults based on specific patient characteristics
Prophylactic antiseizure medication not recommended in adults with AIS
